reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hearthstone. In. SPAAAAACE!

But in all seriousness, if one hasn't already guessed from the screenshots and other reviews, it's so mechanically similar to Hearthstone that it may as well be a reskin. If that fact already turns you off from the game, I don't blame you. A lot of what you'll see in this game is something Hearthstone already does, but with far more polish. Hearthstone is by far the more developed game compared to Star Crusade, and Hearthstone doesn't take itself nearly half as seriously as Star Crusade does. It's not a bad game, but it's difficult to judge Star Crusade on its own merits when much of it is so heavily borrowed from another game.

However, that's not to say that Star Crusade doesn't try to mix things up a little. Where there are obvious similarities, if not downright carbon-copied mechanics/classes with different labels --I'm looking at you Terran(Paladin) and Hierarchy(Priest)-- the game does try to introduce concepts you won't find in Hearthstone like Criticals, Mutate, Soak, Armored, etc. Some mechanics are not very well-explained, though, and tend to be up to the player to figure out (Criticals insta-kill, I think?) and in a CCG, not knowing what your or your enemy's cards do in the middle of a game is bad.

I will say that I'm having fun with the game so far, unpolished as it is. It's certainly worth a try for the novelty of playing a Hearthstone-like game with some different features you won't find in Blizzard's own CCG. Ultimately, it's hard to say if Star Crusade is really trying to be a good alternative to Hearthstone, or if it's a cynical 'follow-the-leader' cash grab hoping to net some Blizzard fans.

For now, I give it a tentative recommendation, if only for novelty's sake and the fact that it's free, but if you're looking for a Hearthstone 2.0, this probably isn't it.

Simply put, Star Crusade is a sublime iteration on the fast-paced, click-n-drag style of digital CCGs first popularized by Hearthstone. Do not let the negative reviews discourage you from hopping into the cockpit of the closest Gargoyle Bomber and taking Star Crusade out for a spin around the galaxy!

Star Crusade has plenty to offer both veteran CCG players and newcomers alike;

Starting health pools that are influenced by the number of cards in a player's deck.

Three slots per deck that can be customized with various modules that alter faction/deck archetypes.

RNG elements are kept to a healthy minimum. In Star Crusade it is Skill, not luck, that determines most games.

A huge core set of cards.

A generous rewards system for those looking to go strictly F2P. No daily cap on in-game credits earned.

Raids (drafts)!
See you in the stars!

Yes the game is very similar to Hearthstone. Good I'm glad that's out of the way.

I am loving and am addicted to this game. I'm a 100% free to play player as well. Yes I can tell buying packs would give you a benefit but honestly you still have to know how to use the cards correctly. This is something you cannot get until you've put some time into the game. By that point though you will have gotten enough credits for several booster packs and can probably make a decent deck for free.

Unlike Hearthstone decks can have anywhere from 25-40 cards. Each player starts with 25 life but for every card more then that in your deck you get another point. So if I have a 25 card deck and my opponent has a 40 card deck I'll start with 25 life and he will start with 40. This may seem bad but honestly it's not. With 25 card decks they are very focused and you have much higher chances of getting the cards you need. In fact I rarely lose to people with 40 card decks but lose to the people rolling 25 all the time lol.

The presentation for the game is top notch as far as I'm concerned. I mean there is only so much you can do with a ccg. I  think it's one of the better looking/sounding card games out there.

Another HUGE plus are the devs. They are very active on the forums and respond to almost any question posted. They have even been known to give people boosters if they report bugs/problems with the game. They may seriously be the most open devs I've ever got a game from.

The one negative I have for the game though is it doesn't do a great job of explaining what different abilities are. I'm positive almost everyone says wtf is firepower" their first few games. This isn't a big issue imo though b/c after a handful of games you'll have a good grasp.

In the end I cannot recomend this game enough. Yes it's very Hearthstone like but unless you're just in love with the Warcraft lore (hey nothing wrong with that!) I really feel as if this game has it beat. It also doesn't hurt that this is new and it does NOT require a significant investment to start if you want to be competitive

DO NOT FALL UNDER THE HATERS THAT SAY THIS GAME IS A PALE COPY OF HEARTHSTONE : READ MY REVIEW FIRST AS THEY PROBABLY PLAYED 5 GAMES THEN LEFT.

Star Crusade is a card game that, yes, take the basic aspects of Hearthstone.  The mechanics will seems pretty familiar to Heartstone players but this is all.  THERE ARE A LOT OF DIFFERENCES TOO!!

1 - DECK SIZE : You deck is not forced to have 30 cards and can range from 25 to 40 (which also decide what are your starting HP).  The beefier your deck, the more HP but less chances to get your combos fast.

2 - ENERGY : Each commander have an energy bank that grows either at the end of your turn or by doing damages to opponent units and commander.  This bank can be use to activate abilities on some cards.

3 - MODULES : The abilities of your commander can be changed with module.  This is changed before the game in the deckbuilder and it defines your modules at the start of the game.  You begin with one and two ''empty spaces'' (you can have a maximum of 3 modules and you can even change the one they give you free).  This leads to different deck mechanics.  Right now, cards are limited but as the game expand it will be a good thing for diversity.

4 - RAID MODE : The raid mode is the ''arena'' of Star Crusade.  It will offers you to make a deck from random cards but you will progress on a map as you win games.  This will lead to different ''candies'' you can get from winning.

If combined, those three aspects really change the game from Hearthstone.  IT IS NOT A PALE COPY even if some cards are direct copy-paste.  Every CCG/TCG have some aspects in common.  They cannot reinvent the wheel !!!

I just started playing this game last Friday (April 29th, 2016) after seeing a gameplay video for it on Christopher Odd's YouTube channel. Even though this game is still in early access as of the writing of this review, I feel that this is one of the best digital CCGs available. The game can be a little difficult at times with the limited player base and on-going balance tweaks that are inherent in any game that is still in development, but the unique setting and approach to gameplay make this a very enjoyable gaming experience. Also, the developers have been extremely generous to the player base, offering two daily quests each day rewarding extra in game credits (used for buying additional card backs and initiating new raids), instituting a reward system for ranked play that provides players with extra booster packs, credits, and scrap (used for crafting individual cards) for reaching key rank thresholds on the ladder each month, and additional rewards for unlocking specific Steam achievments. With all of their generosity, I have yet to spend a single penny on this game and still feel that I am competitive, even against some of the players who have been playing Star Crusade for months and who have nearly full card and module collections. I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with Star Crusade and look forward to all of the upcoming developments.

Edit: Firstly, I want to remind people that this game is still in Early Access Development as of the writing of this update (June 1st, 2016) and as such it is still undergoing significant balance and performance changes. For example, the latest update which released this week has implemented a 5 minute grace period in which you are not supposed to be matched against your previous opponent in either the ranked or raid game modes. This change is a huge quality of life improvement for the game as it reduces the likelihood of entering into the dreaded death spiral" of being matched against the same opponent multiple times in a row which has been a major frustration of the player base at-large for some time.

This is just one example of the changes being made to the game right now and it also highlights the fact that the devs are listening to the feedback the community is providing through the discussion forums and game review posts on Steam

The devs have also made it clear that an improved tutorial system and additional localizations for the game are on their way along with many other new features which they plan to have implemented between now and the official release date for this game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Star Crusade is a collectible digital card game, and my first few days have left me with a very good impression.

The first thing you will notice is how similar it is to hearthstone. I know everyone else has mentioned this, so I will as well. There are many things borrowed, and that can be good and bad.  If you play hearthstone the game will be instantly accessible and comfortable, with a few different powers and keywords to learn. If you are looking for something different, you may find there is enough of a difference to give this one a test, especially if you are not a fan of the RNG, as so many are not. This game shares some elements of hearthstone yes but it is trying to cut its own path.

The graphics are hit and miss, the menus are only OK and the backgrounds are mostly static, but some of the art is absolutely amazing. Some of the cards look like they come right out of an old buck rogers comic or HR Geiger exhibit depending on your race. Some are a  little bit not good (pulse rifles, you need to change right now) But mostly, I really enjoy the look and feel of the game.

The matches are fast and furious, and while starting out the game can be daunting (the first many matches/few days will be harrowing as you build your collection) due to the fact that many people you will be matched with will have much superior decks/know how to play, if you stick with it you will be rewarded with a game that has deceptive depth. The amount of keywords, cards and configurations in the first set is rich and rewarding. Is it as deep as hearthston? not quite, but that game has been out for years. I honestly think this is a much better game out of the gate (and in beta) than hearthstone was when it first launched.

Over all I highly recommend giving this a shot and sticking through the first few missions to grab a few of the rarer cards and trying to learn the ins and outs of the game.

I was inspired to write this review by firstofficer, a (the?) developer who is taking the time to respond and post to everyone who is posting in his forum. Excellent dev support, I see you are listening, the players are out here! Great job so far.

Star Crusade CCG at the first time just looks like another CCG but after playing it you´ll understand how good this game is.

The Good about the Game
You start with basic cards and unlock some others while leveling your heroes (at lvl 9), when you reach lvl 16 you unlock a 2nd module (hero power or hero ability) and you can have 3 at same time. Three modules and a dual resource system (supply and energy) is what makes Star Crusade a great game.
The factions and setting are really nice if you like futuristic scyfy and aliens, there are 6 atm and a new one is coming.
Another interesting thing about the game is that your starting life depends on deck size from 25-40 but some stronger modules can decrease your starting life!
The Devs are really involved in the game and the really listen to the community and try to balance the game.
A booster has 6 cards.

The Bad
Although its easier to get booster packs than in other CCGs the amount of paragon and heroic cards are a bit high in my opinion (46 paragons and 66x2 heroics  atm), and some of them are not very good (this happens in every CCG).
Because there arent many players yet sometimes in ranked games you get matched against really high ranked players the good thing is that you dont loose ranks when that happens.

Overall this game is very good and if you like CCGs this game is for you.

This is a great new CCG and plays like HS but is sci-fi, runs on Steam and overall runs very smooth for being in Beta. The balance among the races is really good as I have been able to win with each one several times. The developer seems to listen and take in community suggestions during the beta/early access and has put out some updates and another one is right around the corner.  Also the prizes and giveaways are generous, more than other games I have played in recent memory which is nice.

Not sure why people downvote the game because it is like Blizzard HS CCG. They are all CCG online games and there is only so much variety, but this one is worth your time if you are sick of HS, like sci-fi or are new to CCG and want to get in and try from the ground up before 100,000 people are playing (which I can only hope for).

Oh and all cards you gain during beta/early access are yours, the game is not being wiped according to developers upon official release 1.0, whenever that will be.

A few things to note for someone just starting off:
1)  there is no help within the game beyond the quick tutorial. (It is planned supposedly but not impletmented yet).  You will feel lost at times, but after about 10 hours and many non-ranked games you get a feel for things fairly quick.  If you have played other CCGs online this curve will be a bit less steep for you.

2)  there are not 100,000 players so at this time during early access you do play a lot of high end players and can/may get frustrated when you start off. I know I did at first and wanted to pitch my screen across the desk after 3 rounds in a row vs top 5 opponent. BUT it is also a great time to learn and debug the game,and once I came to terms with that I have been progressing more and seeing the great CCG that it is.

3)  Raids are great as it is a random pick of 30 cards.  But remember you will not have the experience and knowledge of combos and playstyles under your belt so you will be destroyed 90% of the time until you learn.  Do not waste your credits on Raids until you have a lot of spare credits lying around. Once I stopped raiding and started using the earned credits for packs my non-raid decks got better, i started enjoying the game more, and then I was able to throw in a raid now and again and I win 1 or 2 raid games out of 5 games where I used to lose 3 straight and raid was over. But to each their own, odds are you are better than I am at this game. :)

4)  There is a new players guide up on Steam which wasn't there when I started. Read it. WIll help with the knowledge base and allow you to build a playable deck without all the top cards (which aren't needed as much as I thought).

Let me start off by saying that this is my first CCG. I have never played Hearthstone, MTG, or any of the others. Because of this, I went in having very few expectations. Fortunately, I was pleasantly surprised.

The first think that came as a shock was the easy to learn interface. I've always thought of CCG/TCG's as very complicated games that can take years to learn and collect cards for. However, the tutorial is very comprehensive. I was familiar with the interface in minutes, and had created my own custom deck within the first hour.

Another pleasant surprise was the lack of pay-to-play elements. I've become accustomed to pretty much every free game on Steam being P2P, giving me a greater appreciation for a game that is truly free to play. Yes, there are in-game purchases, but anything that can be bought with actual money is either cosmetic or can be bought with the in-game currency.

Finally, the gameplay was fun. It is a bit unbalanced, as some classes are better than others, and the RNG can be unfair at times, but overall it is still an enjoyable experience. The visual effects are good, much better than those of Spellweaver, another digital CCG that I downloaded after I started Star Crusade. The replayability is nearly infinite, as ranked seasons and daily missions offer reasons to come back to this game time and time again.

Overall, I give it a 7.5/10.

Currently this is my favorite CCG.  I say this as someone who has played Hearthstone, MTG (online and IRL), Might and Magic, and Runescape Legends - just to name a few CCG.  Yet I like this one the best, why?  First of all I simply prefer the aesthetic of this game.  It is the only futuristic card game that I have played in a seemingly endless tide of medieval-fantasy.  That and it is the only CCG I've found where it is truly possible to excel and progress meaningfully, in terms of rank and card collection, without throwing tons of money.  Many CCGs are free-to-play but, oftentimes, pay-to-win-more.  Note that this is how things stand as of the moment I am writing this review; and, as it stands, I have been able to keep a solid winrate and acquire many high-end cards without needing to pay anything.  As someone with not a lot of cash, this is fantastic.

Many will compare this game to Hearthstone, and while that is true (they are very similar on multiple points), the new mechanics of having multiple, exchangeable hero powers and also have Energy as a second resource to Supply makes this game feel completely new and fresh.  As someone who played Hearthstone from the beta, I now find Star Crusade to be a much more compelling experience simply because the devs are not afraid to print cards that are extremely powerful or can create mega combos.  Right of the gate some of the best cards in the game are given to you as basics - it's just up for you to figure them out.

Personally, I have had tons of fun with this game and I cannot understand why it is so poorly received.  Most likely, people have not given it the time of day to understand that Star Crusade does enough different to excite someone who has played other CCGs while maintaining a similar formula that will leave you feeling comfortable.  It is vastly underrated - I love this game, as it stands so far.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Star Crusade CCG is a very good free-to-play (F2P) card game. If you like the (real life) card games Magic The Gathering or NetRunner, you'll love this game.

Cons:

- Currently, you can only chat with your opponent if he already is in your friends list. At least, one can use several emotes. Fortunately, no chat means no spamming and no insulting by kiddies. They may add a chat later.
- Some cards are still inbalanced (e.g. Modules) but balancing is in progress (the game is still in beta).
- You'll encounter a bug from time to time, but overall the game is very stable.
- Often it takes a while to find games because the player base isn't very big. Probably, this will improve when the game will be released on further platforms (e.g. mobile) and when the game will leave the Beta phase.

Pros:

- In my opinion, the game currently isn't pay-to-win (P2W). How many money someone spent on the game doesn't make a huge difference. It is more important to know how to build good decks (i.e. skill) than to have all rare cards. Of course, it will make things easier by buying a few booster packs (the company somehow has to make some money to pay the developers, doesn't it?).
- The game is rather generous. You can earn cards for free by winning against opponents, finishing daily quests, finding promo codes (e.g. in the forums) and by having an improved rank at the end of a season.
- Scrap mechanic: You can melt duplicate or unneeded cards to forge new cards. This means that, theoretically, you can choose from all existing cards. Of course, the rare cards will cost a lot of scrap but that's still better than having to depend on finding a certain card in a booster.
- The luck factor in the game is just right. You'll lose if you just depend on luck instead of building a decent deck. However, there is still enough luck involved to make the game exciting.
- Good graphics and sound effects.
- Space theme. The theme is very varied. It doesn't reduce to space ships!
- It is possible to play against bots in Practice and Casual Mode. You'll automatically play against a bot in Casual Mode, if you can't find an opponent after a certain time. The bots currently are very dumb but they are sufficient to learn the game and to level your heroes.

If you still are not convinced that the game is good, download and install it! It is free to play.

This review is about Star Crusade 1.0.2.5.S822 (Beta).

Started as a heartstone clone, now it diverged quite a bit with modules (in HS term, you can run up to 3 hero powers).
It's something similar yet different enough that it can stand on its own.

Different Heroes with different focus and sets of skills

Energy mechanics (a second resource that's require to use certain hero powers)
Limited amount of RNG (unlike the current HS meta)

Cons -
Paragons modules can end a game before you even start
Broken comboes that you can't avoid or break unless your win condition is faster than their win condition (Null, this game version of Silence effect, doesn't affect influence from modules). There are decks that literally lock you out of your deck and fill you hand with trash that hurts you every turn, so it's absolutely no fun.
Broken modules that makes it so that that you can't win as an average F2P player. The Terran (their version of the paladin) has a paragon module that give them -1/+1 on your turn and +1/-1 on theirs, literally impossible to win with newb decks.

I will reluctantly recommend this game. It has its flaws, but it's different and it's still being developed, if they can fix the brokenness of their highest tier cards, then it could very well become a game that can rival hearthstone.

Early Access Review:  Has the same pay / grind mechanics that a lot of other games do.  If you're into paying or grinding to keep up with the field, pick this game up by all means.  Some critics say this game's a Hearthstone clone, but Star Crusade CCG *does* have unique elements that make it worth looking at.  But the pay/grind wall makes this a title I can't recommend at this time.

As it is, other computer CCGs that I know of similarly have pay / grind walls, so I'm continuing to play this on and off.  But the moment a good computer CCG comes along, I'm dropping this title completely.  (Unless this game makes changes to the pay/grind structure, then I'll stick with this one.  But that hasn't happened yet, and there's no sign it will at this time.)

(edit) Noted a developer commented on my review.  On the day after Christmas, no less.  But the mentioned changes do not alter the fundamental pay / grind mechanics.   Dropping the daily limit, changing daily-missions-for-in-game-credit - there are pros and cons to each, but essentially neither changes the basic situation.

As to top decks containing few heroic/paragon tier cards, - well, if there are expansions for the game (and why not, that's the nature of CCGs), then more heroic / paragon tier cards will be released, and those will be rotated into more competitive decks.  Over time, this will mean decks will contain more and more rare cards, so players just joining will face a massive pay / grind wall to try to be competitive, and players that are already playing will have to pay or grind to keep up.  It won't be a sudden and drastic change with the next expansion, but over time there'll be a considerable cumulative effect.

Mind, though, just because the developer didn't fully address the pay / grind mechanic, doesn't mean they are unaware, or that they intend to ignore those concerns.  Even if they *did* intend to change things, and immediately, it's a huge change of direction.  That means talks with financing, discussions, conferences, meetings, &c.  Of course, they might *already* have had those meetings and had some theoretical scenarios based on anticipated monetizations but . . . they chose to do things as they did, as they are currently implemented.  Changing at this point is not something that will be done lightly (if at all.)

So though I must commend the developer on the quick response (especially on the day after Christmas), I do not change my review to one in favor of the game, as I think the pay / grind mechanic is still the major issue.

Again, for players that really don't care about a pay / grind wall, by all means, I think it's not badly done.  I can make some observations about the art being gender discriminatory, or say the mechanics are limited by the current design (they are), or make other criticisms, but the fact is they *have* done some interesting things with this game that are well worth checking out - provided you go in with your eyes open and know what you're getting into.

Early Access Review

Firstly, I know this is a beta. That being said, unless they are planning a major overhaul-- which I assume isn't the case this close to launch-- there are severe inherant balance issues that are intrinsic to the game in its current state.

The largest detriment here is the steamroll effect. As anyone knows, a well balanced game always has a chance-- even if its small-- to comeback from behind. It is non-existent in this game. There is an illusion of coming back, but it's entirely up to chance and not to strategy. Once one player starts steamrolling, the opponent has literally zero chance of coming back unless the winner just starts drawing nothing. There's no chance for the loser to come back with the cards they have, the only way is for the winner to just start losing. That's it. So most games are won within the first 4-5 turns but still have to played out. As an avid CCG fan, I should feel like the chances are based on what's in my deck, not what the opponent draws. This even makes winning a bore.

The other large detriment is yet another money grab game. I've played for about 7 hours and still was only able to get enough credits to open 3-4 packs of cards. On top of that, I only got 2 or 3 of those cards that are actually compatible with my deck. It is painfully obvious the only way to get anything is paying real money. If you want us to give you money, just make us buy the game. Developers need to stop giving the illusion that a f2p game can have any chance against paid users.

There are elements of a good game hidden here: aesthetic, hero abilities, easy format, and good combos. Unfortunately they are far too weak and everything else cripples them.

I would say wait until the actual release but there aren't any kinks to be worked out, there's just hemorrhaging gashes that turn this game into yet another pay to win.

Early Access Review

Fun, very polished, and not reliant on insane RNG?  What's not to like?

Inevitably people will call this a reskinned Hearthstone.  Although they obviously iterated their designed off of what Blizzard did, I think Star Crusade is more fun.  There's a lot of additional complexity with deck building thanks to the Hero Module system.  Far more faction specific mechanics to actually make the faction choices matter.  Lastly, I haven't felt this INSANE randomness reliance that Hearthstone has.

It doesn't feel like you're losing games on a 50/50 coin toss, but rather on the strength of your deck and your piloting of it.

I also really like the idea of being able to adjust my health pool through my deck size, punishing aggressive decks for their consistency.
